text:
MITIGATION MEASURES
Thailand has made efforts to uphold its commitment under the Convention by
integrating climate change mitigation into its national and sectoral policies and plans
and implementing mitigating measures in order to achieve the national GHG reduction
targets—NAMA’s target to reduce GHG emissions by 7-20% from BAU by 2020 and
NDC’s target to reduce GHG emission by 20-25% from BAU by 2030.
prompted_docs:
MITIGATION MEASURES
Thailand has made efforts to uphold its commitment under the Convention by
integrating climate change mitigation into its national and sectoral policies and plans
and implementing mitigating measures in order to achieve the national GHG reduction
targets—NAMA’s target to reduce GHG emissions by 7-20% from BAU by 2020 and
NDC’s target to reduce GHG emission by 20-25% from BAU by 2030.
responses: [1] Climate Change: The document discusses Thailand's efforts to integrate climate change mitigation into its policies and plans, specifically mentioning GHG reduction targets. ("Thailand has made efforts to uphold its commitment under the Convention by integrating climate change mitigation into its national and sectoral policies and plans and implementing mitigating measures in order to achieve the national GHG reduction targets—NAMA’s target to reduce GHG emissions by 7-20% from BAU by 2020 and NDC’s target to reduce GHG emission by 20-25% from BAU by 2030.")

text:
Thailand submitted
the 2nd updated NDC, which aligns with an ambitious pledge to reduce GHG emissions
by 30% from the BAU level by 2030.
prompted_docs:
Thailand submitted
the 2nd updated NDC, which aligns with an ambitious pledge to reduce GHG emissions
by 30% from the BAU level by 2030.
responses: [1] Environment: The document discusses Thailand's commitment to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, which is a key environmental issue. ("...aligns with an ambitious pledge to reduce GHG emissions by 30% from the BAU level by 2030.")

text:
The contribution level increases to 40%, subject
to adequate and enhanced access to technology development and transfer, financial
resources, and capacity-building support.
prompted_docs:
The contribution level increases to 40%, subject
to adequate and enhanced access to technology development and transfer, financial
resources, and capacity-building support.
responses: [1] Technology: The document discusses access to technology development and transfer, which is relevant to the topic of technology. ("...subject to adequate and enhanced access to technology development and transfer...")

text:
Furthermore, Thailand will continue efforts to
meet the long-term goals of carbon neutrality by 2050 and net-zero GHG emissions
by 2065.
Thailand implemented NAMA’s mitigation measures and successfully achieved a GHG
reduction of 56.54 MtCO2eq in 2020 from 10 mitigation measures in the energy and
transport sectors which is 15.40% lower than its BAU level.
prompted_docs:
Furthermore, Thailand will continue efforts to
meet the long-term goals of carbon neutrality by 2050 and net-zero GHG emissions
by 2065.
Thailand implemented NAMA’s mitigation measures and successfully achieved a GHG
reduction of 56.54 MtCO2eq in 2020 from 10 mitigation measures in the energy and
transport sectors which is 15.40% lower than its BAU level.
responses: [1] Environment: The document discusses Thailand's efforts towards carbon neutrality and GHG emissions reduction, which are key environmental goals. ("Thailand will continue efforts to meet the long-term goals of carbon neutrality by 2050 and net-zero GHG emissions by 2065.")

text:
As NAMA ended in 2020,
Thailand has transitioned toward NDC, which aims to reduce GHG emissions in the
energy, transport, industrial process and product use, and waste management sectors.
In addition, Thailand has also increasingly developed supporting measures and
voluntary actions to mitigate GHG reduction, such as the carbon market and carbon
label schemes.

Figure: Thailand’s GHG emission reduction from NAMA implementation 2013-2020

 THAILAND'S FOURTH NATIONAL COMMUNICATION
VULNERABILITY AND ADAPTATION
Thailand, a developing country, is ranked 9th as the most affected country by climate
change impacts in the last 20 years (2000-2019) by Global Climate Risk Index 2021
(CRI), both in terms of human impacts (fatalities) and direct economic losses.
prompted_docs:
As NAMA ended in 2020,
Thailand has transitioned toward NDC, which aims to reduce GHG emissions in the
energy, transport, industrial process and product use, and waste management sectors.
In addition, Thailand has also increasingly developed supporting measures and
voluntary actions to mitigate GHG reduction, such as the carbon market and carbon
label schemes.

Figure: Thailand’s GHG emission reduction from NAMA implementation 2013-2020

 THAILAND'S FOURTH NATIONAL COMMUNICATION
VULNERABILITY AND ADAPTATION
Thailand, a developing country, is ranked 9th as the most affected country by climate
change impacts in the last 20 years (2000-2019) by Global Climate Risk Index 2021
(CRI), both in terms of human impacts (fatalities) and direct economic losses.
responses:
[1] Climate Change: The document discusses Thailand's efforts to reduce GHG emissions and its vulnerability to climate change impacts. ("Thailand has transitioned toward NDC, which aims to reduce GHG emissions in the energy, transport, industrial process and product use, and waste management sectors.") 

[2] Environmental Policy: The document mentions Thailand's development of measures to mitigate GHG reduction, indicating a focus on environmental policy. ("Thailand has also increasingly developed supporting measures and voluntary actions to mitigate GHG reduction, such as the carbon market and carbon label schemes.") 

[3] Vulnerability and Adaptation: The document highlights Thailand's ranking as one of the most affected countries by climate change, which relates to vulnerability and adaptation strategies. ("Thailand, a developing country, is ranked 9th as the most affected country by climate change impacts in the last 20 years...")

text:
Thailand,
by ONEP and RU-CORE, has developed a database of geospatial risks from climate
change by assessing climate impacts, risks, and vulnerabilities in 6 significant sectors:
water management, agriculture and food security, tourism, public health, natural
resources management, and human settlement and security.
prompted_docs:
Thailand,
by ONEP and RU-CORE, has developed a database of geospatial risks from climate
change by assessing climate impacts, risks, and vulnerabilities in 6 significant sectors:
water management, agriculture and food security, tourism, public health, natural
resources management, and human settlement and security.
responses: [1] Agriculture: The document discusses the assessment of climate impacts and risks in the agriculture sector. ("...assessing climate impacts, risks, and vulnerabilities in 6 significant sectors: ... agriculture and food security...")

text:
The risk and vulnerability
assessments for climate projection are based on the top-down approach using climate
scenarios generated through the most updated version of General Circulation Models
(GCMs) and RCP models, which are derived from data in the SEACLID/CORDEX SEA
Phase II project.
prompted_docs:
The risk and vulnerability
assessments for climate projection are based on the top-down approach using climate
scenarios generated through the most updated version of General Circulation Models
(GCMs) and RCP models, which are derived from data in the SEACLID/CORDEX SEA
Phase II project.
responses: [1] Climate: The document discusses risk and vulnerability assessments for climate projections based on climate scenarios and models. ("The risk and vulnerability assessments for climate projection are based on the top-down approach using climate scenarios generated through the most updated version of General Circulation Models (GCMs) and RCP models...")

text:
For all the 6 sectors, 3 types of climate hazards—heat, drought, and
flooding—are considered together with socio-economic factors.
prompted_docs:
For all the 6 sectors, 3 types of climate hazards—heat, drought, and
flooding—are considered together with socio-economic factors.
responses: [1] Climate: The document discusses climate hazards and their impact on various sectors, specifically mentioning heat, drought, and flooding. ("For all the 6 sectors, 3 types of climate hazards—heat, drought, and flooding—are considered together with socio-economic factors.")

text:
The vulnerability
assessments show that climate impacts are not homogenous across hazard, type, time,
and areas.
prompted_docs:
The vulnerability
assessments show that climate impacts are not homogenous across hazard, type, time,
and areas.
responses: [1] Climate: The document discusses the variability of climate impacts across different factors, indicating a focus on climate-related issues. ("climate impacts are not homogenous across hazard, type, time, and areas.")

text:
Different sectors and different regions in Thailand are vulnerable to different
climate hazards.
prompted_docs:
Different sectors and different regions in Thailand are vulnerable to different
climate hazards.
responses: [1] Agriculture: The document discusses the vulnerability of different sectors in Thailand to climate hazards, which can impact agricultural productivity and food security. ("Different sectors and different regions in Thailand are vulnerable to different climate hazards.")

text:
In addition to the physical impacts of climate change, Thailand is also
vulnerable to changes in socio-economic conditions, particularly the aging population.

OTHER RELEVANT INFORMATION AND ACTIVITIES
Chapter 5 depicts other information and activities of climate actions that complement
and empower the implementation of mitigation and adaptation measures enabling
Thailand to achieve the objectives of the Convention.
prompted_docs:
In addition to the physical impacts of climate change, Thailand is also
vulnerable to changes in socio-economic conditions, particularly the aging population.

OTHER RELEVANT INFORMATION AND ACTIVITIES
Chapter 5 depicts other information and activities of climate actions that complement
and empower the implementation of mitigation and adaptation measures enabling
Thailand to achieve the objectives of the Convention.
responses: [1] Climate Change: Discusses the impacts of climate change on Thailand, including socio-economic conditions ("In addition to the physical impacts of climate change, Thailand is also vulnerable to changes in socio-economic conditions...")

text:
The information and activities
include technology development and transfer; research and systematic observation;
education, training, public awareness, public participation, and public access to climate
information; capacity building; and information sharing and networking.
prompted_docs:
The information and activities
include technology development and transfer; research and systematic observation;
education, training, public awareness, public participation, and public access to climate
information; capacity building; and information sharing and networking.
responses: [1] Climate: The document discusses various activities related to climate, including technology development, research, and public awareness. ("The information and activities include technology development and transfer; research and systematic observation; education, training, public awareness...")

text:
First, Thailand
has established a mechanism for technology transfer and formulated a climate
technology database and roadmap indicating technologies that require further
development aligning with key sectors stated in Thailand's NDC and Thailand's NAP.
Significant technologies have been developed to reach carbon neutrality and net-zero
targets in the energy sector, such as technologies related to electric vehicles and
hydrogen fuel.
prompted_docs:
First, Thailand
has established a mechanism for technology transfer and formulated a climate
technology database and roadmap indicating technologies that require further
development aligning with key sectors stated in Thailand's NDC and Thailand's NAP.
Significant technologies have been developed to reach carbon neutrality and net-zero
targets in the energy sector, such as technologies related to electric vehicles and
hydrogen fuel.
responses: [1] Climate Change: The document discusses Thailand's efforts in technology transfer and development related to climate goals, specifically mentioning carbon neutrality and net-zero targets. ("...Significant technologies have been developed to reach carbon neutrality and net-zero targets in the energy sector...")

text:
Second, research and systematic observation have been conducted
in climate variable sectors: atmospheric, terrestrial (i.e., land and water), and oceanic
domains.
prompted_docs:
Second, research and systematic observation have been conducted
in climate variable sectors: atmospheric, terrestrial (i.e., land and water), and oceanic
domains.
responses: [1] Climate: The document discusses research and observation in various climate variable sectors, indicating a focus on climate-related studies. ("...research and systematic observation have been conducted in climate variable sectors: atmospheric, terrestrial (i.e., land and water), and oceanic domains.")

text:
Third, Thailand has engaged in implementing capacity-building initiatives
as well as Actions for Climate Empowerment (ACE) under Article 6 of the UNFCCC,
which involves not only climate knowledge dissemination but also the environmental
rights of the public to participate and access climate information.
prompted_docs:
Third, Thailand has engaged in implementing capacity-building initiatives
as well as Actions for Climate Empowerment (ACE) under Article 6 of the UNFCCC,
which involves not only climate knowledge dissemination but also the environmental
rights of the public to participate and access climate information.
responses: [1] Climate Change: The document discusses Thailand's initiatives related to climate knowledge dissemination and public participation in climate information, which are key aspects of climate change actions. ("Thailand has engaged in implementing capacity-building initiatives as well as Actions for Climate Empowerment (ACE) under Article 6 of the UNFCCC, which involves not only climate knowledge dissemination but also the environmental rights of the public to participate and access climate information.")

text:
Finally, ONEP acts
as a primary entity for climate information sharing, and Thailand cooperates with
international communities at bilateral, regional, and multilateral levels to address
climate change issues.

 CONSTRAINTS, GAPS, NEEDS, AND SUPPORT RECEIVED
Thailand has received support from various international partners to facilitate
climate actions in mitigation, adaptation, and enabling environment, including
the preparation of Thailand's Fourth National Communication (NC4) and Third Biennial
Update Report (BUR3) to the UNFCCC.
prompted_docs:
Finally, ONEP acts
as a primary entity for climate information sharing, and Thailand cooperates with
international communities at bilateral, regional, and multilateral levels to address
climate change issues.

 CONSTRAINTS, GAPS, NEEDS, AND SUPPORT RECEIVED
Thailand has received support from various international partners to facilitate
climate actions in mitigation, adaptation, and enabling environment, including
the preparation of Thailand's Fourth National Communication (NC4) and Third Biennial
Update Report (BUR3) to the UNFCCC.
responses: [1] Climate Change: The document discusses Thailand's cooperation with international communities to address climate change issues and mentions support received for climate actions. ("Thailand cooperates with international communities at bilateral, regional, and multilateral levels to address climate change issues.")

text:
From 2020-2022, Thailand has received support
from multilateral and bilateral partners for a total of 34 projects, entailing 18 mitigation
projects with a total amount of 31,438,771 USD, 10 adaptation projects with a total
amount of 48,667,056 USD, and 6 enabling environment projects with a total amount
of 3,419,548 USD.
prompted_docs:
From 2020-2022, Thailand has received support
from multilateral and bilateral partners for a total of 34 projects, entailing 18 mitigation
projects with a total amount of 31,438,771 USD, 10 adaptation projects with a total
amount of 48,667,056 USD, and 6 enabling environment projects with a total amount
of 3,419,548 USD.
responses: [1] Climate Change: The document discusses various projects related to mitigation and adaptation, which are key components of climate change initiatives. ("...18 mitigation projects with a total amount of 31,438,771 USD, 10 adaptation projects with a total amount of 48,667,056 USD...")

text:
Most support was a combination of technical support and capacity
building.
However, considering remaining constraints and gaps, Thailand still needs international
support in terms of finance, technical expertise, technology transfer, and capacity
building to ensure the achievement of LT-LEDS in a short-term period (2025-2035), a
mid-term period (2040-2050), and a long-term period (2050-2065).
prompted_docs:
Most support was a combination of technical support and capacity
building.
However, considering remaining constraints and gaps, Thailand still needs international
support in terms of finance, technical expertise, technology transfer, and capacity
building to ensure the achievement of LT-LEDS in a short-term period (2025-2035), a
mid-term period (2040-2050), and a long-term period (2050-2065).
responses: [1] Agriculture: The document discusses the need for international support in terms of capacity building and technical expertise, which is relevant to agricultural development and sustainability efforts in Thailand. ("Thailand still needs international support in terms of finance, technical expertise, technology transfer, and capacity building...")

text:
More support is
needed, particularly for technology development and transfer, which is essential for
mitigation and adaptation implementation.
prompted_docs:
More support is
needed, particularly for technology development and transfer, which is essential for
mitigation and adaptation implementation.
responses: [1] Technology: The document discusses the need for support in technology development and transfer, which is crucial for implementation related to mitigation and adaptation. ("More support is needed, particularly for technology development and transfer...")

text:
For mitigation, Thailand needs support
for the energy transition toward renewable sources focusing on renewable energy
technologies (such as solar and wind), enhancing the potential use of Carbon Capture
Storage (CCS) & Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) technologies, and
developing other technologies to achieve GHG emission reduction and a net-zero
emission.
prompted_docs:
For mitigation, Thailand needs support
for the energy transition toward renewable sources focusing on renewable energy
technologies (such as solar and wind), enhancing the potential use of Carbon Capture
Storage (CCS) & Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) technologies, and
developing other technologies to achieve GHG emission reduction and a net-zero
emission.
responses: [1] Energy: The document discusses the need for support in transitioning to renewable energy sources and mentions specific technologies aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions. ("...support for the energy transition toward renewable sources focusing on renewable energy technologies (such as solar and wind)...")

text:
For adaptation, support is needed for developing a data map showing areas at
risk of climate change impacts and accessible viable adaptive technology.
prompted_docs:
For adaptation, support is needed for developing a data map showing areas at
risk of climate change impacts and accessible viable adaptive technology.
responses: [1] Climate Change: The document discusses the need for support in developing a data map related to climate change impacts ("...support is needed for developing a data map showing areas at risk of climate change impacts...").

text:
To enhance
the enabling environment, Thailand requires support for developing and strengthening
mechanisms, instruments, and policy implementation, such as financial instruments
and incentives to engage private sectors in green investment and capacity building for
all stakeholders to integrate climate actions into their respective practice and plans.
prompted_docs:
To enhance
the enabling environment, Thailand requires support for developing and strengthening
mechanisms, instruments, and policy implementation, such as financial instruments
and incentives to engage private sectors in green investment and capacity building for
all stakeholders to integrate climate actions into their respective practice and plans.
responses: [1] Climate Change: The document discusses the need for mechanisms and policies to support climate actions, indicating a focus on climate-related initiatives. ("...support for developing and strengthening mechanisms, instruments, and policy implementation...to integrate climate actions into their respective practice and plans.")

text:
The macroeconomics projections up to 2030 are then used to generate energy
demand functions using the regression software Microfit2.
prompted_docs:
The macroeconomics projections up to 2030 are then used to generate energy
demand functions using the regression software Microfit2.
responses: [1] Energy: The document discusses generating energy demand functions, which relates directly to energy topics. ("...generate energy demand functions using the regression software Microfit2.")

text:
The energy demand
functions generated then is used to estimate the final energy demand and supply
projections and GHG emissions for the energy sector.
3.3.2 Summary of GHG Emission Projection Results
The projection indicates that the total emissions without LULUCF for Malaysia would
be 481,363 Gg CO2 eq for the WOM case by 2030 (Figure 3.1 and Table 3.5).
Continued implementation of the planned activities under the WEM scenario would
bring the emissions down to 367,603 Gg CO2 eq.
prompted_docs:
The energy demand
functions generated then is used to estimate the final energy demand and supply
projections and GHG emissions for the energy sector.
3.3.2 Summary of GHG Emission Projection Results
The projection indicates that the total emissions without LULUCF for Malaysia would
be 481,363 Gg CO2 eq for the WOM case by 2030 (Figure 3.1 and Table 3.5).
Continued implementation of the planned activities under the WEM scenario would
bring the emissions down to 367,603 Gg CO2 eq.
responses: [1] Energy: The document discusses energy demand and GHG emissions projections for the energy sector, indicating a focus on energy-related topics. ("The projection indicates that the total emissions without LULUCF for Malaysia would be 481,363 Gg CO2 eq for the WOM case by 2030...")

text:
If further mitigation activities under
the WAM scenario are carried out, the GHG emissions could reduce to 337,554 Gg
CO2 eq.
prompted_docs:
If further mitigation activities under
the WAM scenario are carried out, the GHG emissions could reduce to 337,554 Gg
CO2 eq.
responses: [1] Environment: The document discusses the potential reduction of greenhouse gas emissions under a specific scenario, which relates directly to environmental concerns. ("If further mitigation activities under the WAM scenario are carried out, the GHG emissions could reduce to 337,554 Gg CO2 eq.")

text:
The mitigation assumptions for each of the scenarios and sectors are
described in section 3.3.3.

Figure 3.1: Projected Greenhouse Gas Emission Time Series for WOM, WEM
and WAM Scenarios

The energy sector is projected to continue to be the largest contributor of GHG
emissions in 2030 followed by the IPPU and waste sectors.
prompted_docs:

and WAM Scenarios

The energy sector is projected to continue to be the largest contributor of GHG
emissions in 2030 followed by the IPPU and waste sectors.
responses: [1] Environment: Discusses greenhouse gas emissions and their contributors, specifically mentioning the energy sector as a major source ("The energy sector is projected to continue to be the largest contributor of GHG emissions in 2030...").

text:
For the WEM scenario
without LULUCF, the GHG emissions from the energy sector is likely to be 80% of the
total emissions in 2030.
prompted_docs:
For the WEM scenario
without LULUCF, the GHG emissions from the energy sector is likely to be 80% of the
total emissions in 2030.
responses: [1] Environment: The document discusses greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from the energy sector, which is a key environmental issue. ("...the GHG emissions from the energy sector is likely to be 80% of the total emissions in 2030.")

text:
This is followed by the IPPU sector at around 11%, the waste
sector at about 6% and the agriculture sector at 3%.
prompted_docs:
This is followed by the IPPU sector at around 11%, the waste
sector at about 6% and the agriculture sector at 3%.
responses: [1] Agriculture: Mentions the contribution of the agriculture sector to emissions ("the agriculture sector at 3%").

text:
For the WAM scenario without
LULUCF, the energy sector is likely to account for 78% of the emissions in 2030.

For the WAM scenario without
LULUCF, the energy sector is likely to account for 78% of the emissions in 2030.
responses: [1] Energy: The document discusses the energy sector's contribution to emissions, indicating its significance in the context of climate change. ("the energy sector is likely to account for 78% of the emissions in 2030.")
